talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Macdonald, the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âSenator Mackay shows the difference between the Labor approach to assisting rural and regional Australia and the government approach. Our approach is going to the communities and asking them, `What are your problems? What do you need with a rural transaction centre? What transactions facilities are you missing? What don't you have?' We then say to the community, `You tell us how you would like to resolve that problem and we will pay to fix it. We are not going to sit in Canberra and say to you, "This is how you should do it; this is the best way to suit you."' We do not get a central agency like Australia Post to say, `We know what's better for Eugowra,' or, `We know what's better for Aramac and Eugowra than the people of Aramac or Eugowra.' We ask the people of Aramac, the people of Dirranbandi, the people of St Marys in your own state, Senator, and we say to them, `What are you lacking? What do you need? How would you like to resolve it? Would you like Australia Post to do it, or would you like the Trust Bank or a credit union to come in and do it, or would you like the Pioneer Building Society in Aramac to come in and provide the banking service? If that is what you wantâor if you want Centrelink there, Medicare Ezyclaim, a fax machine put thereâyou tell us what you want and then we will provide it.'

answer.para: That is exactly what has happened. Sure, Australia Post have said, `Yes, we could do this.' We have written to Australia Post and said, `By all means, if the community wants you to do that, then please do it: please get the community to write in and suggest yourselves.' In Aramac, an RTC that I intend to open in the middle of November is at the licensed post office. Many of the places where the first rounds were set up are in licensed post offices because that is what the community wantedânot what Senator Mackay wanted, not what I wanted, not what Australia Post wanted but what the community itself wanted.
That is our approach. It is an approach of consulting with the community, asking what they want, and not telling them from Canberra or any other central agency what is best for them.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it that that was a yes, that Australia Post was blocked from providing a holistic approach. talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian

talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âAnother minute to try to open Senator Mackay's ears. Australia Post was not blockedân-o-tânot blocked. We asked the community, `Do you want Australia Post?' In any instances they said, `Yes, we do,' they would get it. But in some instances they said, `No, we want Trust Bank to do it,' or, `We want someone else to do it.' âMy question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Minchin. The Howard government recognises the importance of the automotive industry to the economic wellbeing of the Australian community. How are the government's policies working to encourage employment and investment in Australia's car industry?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Ferguson for his question. Senator Ferguson, as a South Australian, of course, has a very keen interest in the car industry. Last week we had the opposition spreading gloom and doom about the industry, but I want to confirm for the Senate that the prospects for this industry both for the short term and the long term are very good. As I have often said in this place, last yearâ1998âwas a record year for the car industry, with sales of 807,000 compared with 720,000-odd the year before, which was itself a record. So, under 3Â½ years of this government, the car industry has had its two best years ever in the history of the automotive industry in Australia.

answer.para: The reasons for this I think were very well set out by Mike Kable, the eminent and well-respected motoring writer, in last Thursday's Australian, where he said:

Last year, . . . was a freak because of factors including public confidence in a strong economy, fierce price competition at the "cheap and cheerful" end of the market, new models in all segments and very favourable interest and lease rates.

So we have the position that the economic policies of the government, with strong demand and low interest rates, have produced a very strong car industry and a record year for the industry. Mike Kable went on to write:
After such a boom year, a slackening of demand was inevitable, irrespective of the GST.
He refuted claims that there was some sort of buyers strike. In his article, which was headed `Car-makers overplay the GST slump card', he wrote:
The good news is that the situation is not as bad as it sounds, despite the industry's best endeavours to pressure the Federal Government into giving it a tax break . . .

The fact is that car sales, in 1999, are still very strong. Just last Friday, Peter Sturrock, the Chief Executive of the Chamber of Automotive Industries, repeated the chamber's forecast that 1999 will be the second-best year ever for Australian car sales. They are still anticipating 760,000 sales this year, the second-best ever in Australian history. Look at what happened under Labor. In their last year in officeâ1995âthere were 640,000 car sales. We are being criticised by Labor, who are spreading gloom and doom, because this year we are having 120,000 more car sales than we had in the last year of the Labor Party's government.

There was a report, noted by Labor, about car stocks building up, but in the Herald Sun a Ford executive clearly rejected that that could be blamed only on the GST. He said that the two important factors in Ford's case for a build-up in cars were that they were building cars at the same rate as they were in 1998, despite the inevitability, as Mike Kable pointed out, of a slackening this year and, of course, the slow acceptance of the AU Falcon.

What about the long-term prospects for the industry? According to Peter Sturrock's speech last Friday at the Sydney Motor Show, the industry is forecasting a surge in car sales after the introduction of the GST, with vehicle sales, in 2003, forecast at 950,000 vehicles.

talk.start.para: âWe're going to vehicles nowânot cars, vehicles.

âThat is 310,000 more cars sold than were sold in Labor's last year in officeâa 50 per cent increase in the sales of cars. That is all attributed to the GST. There are very clear reasons for the optimism about the car industry. The first is that we have lower car prices because of our tax reformâ
âYou've finally got it right.
âOrder! Senator Murphy, you have been persistently interjecting during this answer. I draw your attention to the standing orders and ask you to abide by them.

âWe have very good reasons for optimism. We have lower car prices because of our tax reforms; we have a strong economy because of our economic policies, which are producing low interest rates and making cars much more affordable; and as of last week we had the parliamentary passage, at last, of the government's $2 billion assistance scheme and tariff freeze which will be a significant boost to investment and R&D in this great Australian industry.

talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

âI have a question for the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Macdonald. The question is: how will the government's tax reform package benefit Australia's local government authorities? talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âSenator Eggleston, perceptively, has asked a question which has two elements. It is perceptive because Senator Eggleston was a very distinguished Mayor of Port Hedland in his former life. He joins Senator Heffernan, who was president of a shire, and Senator Calvert, who was warden of a council in Tasmania. We have a real interest in local government on this side of the House. The tax reform package is excellent for local government because local governments will pay GST on their operations but will get all the GST fully and immediately refunded; 95 per cent of the services which councils provide for their customers, the ratepayers, will be absolutely GST free; and local governments will save tremendously from removal of 7c a litre on all fuel for councils in rural and regional Australia, and heavier transport trucks will get reductions of some 23c a litre in fuel costs. In addition to that there will be the removal of embedded wholesale sales tax that the councils will no longer have to payâa saving of about $70 million Australia wide.

answer.para: A number of studies have been done which show that councils will benefit very considerably. A Victorian government assessment by Arthur Andersen, the auditors and consultants, has shown that annual cost savings to councils will range from about $2 million per annum for an inner metropolitan council, to about $1.2 for an outer metropolitan council and about $400,000 for a regional council. The assessment shows that the cash flow effects will be zero, so there will be no problem to councils there, and it indicates that there will be a one-off implementation cost ranging from $45,000 to $200,000, and that is similar to the Queensland assessmentâand we acknowledge that. But the government has provided money to councils.

Yesterday, Senator Mackay raised with me the Western Australian Municipal Association, saying how unhappy they are. Unfortunately, yesterday I did not have this with me when Senator Mackay raised the matter, but I now quote from a letter dated 14 September in which Councillor Jamie Edwards, the President of WAMA, said:
Your recognition of the need to provide direct assistance to Local Government to facilitate the sector's compliance with the GST and associated reform measures is timely and commendable . . .
This funding signals the strength of what I already believe to be an excellent working relationship with the Federal Government.
My relationship with WAMA is very good. He has said more praiseworthy things about me in that letter, but my natural modesty prevents me from tabling it.

Senator Eggleston also raised with me how these benefits add to the other benefits that local councils have received from the Howard government's consistency in responsible economic management. One of the big things that councils have got from our government is a reduction in interest rates. Average debt across Australia is about $10 million per council. When I left my council just before coming to this place, we were paying something like 15 per cent per annum interest on the loans we had. The interest rate for councils today is six to seven per cent. That is an eight per cent saving in interest that councils are paying on loans because of the Howard government. That equates to a saving of $800,000 a year saving for councils. (Time expired)

For the benefit of those senators who may not be as familiar with this matter as Senator Harradine, I remind the Senate that the agreement is being negotiated by the Victorian Department of Human Services in line with a resolution of the community services ministerial council and that negotiations with the Chinese government have been continuing for some time.

answer.para: Of course, a major obstacle to the agreement was that Australian law did not provide for automatic recognition of Chinese adoptions. That obstacle was overcome when, to facilitate the making of this agreement, the Family Law Act was amended in July 1998 to allow the automatic recognition of adoptions made under bilateral agreements with countries prescribed for that purpose. Pursuant to that, the Family Law Bilateral Arrangements Intercountry Adoptions Regulations of 1998, which prescribed China for that purpose, were made by the Executive Council on 31 July 1998 and commenced on 6 August 1998. Amendments to the migration regulations to allow for the permanent entry of children adopted under the proposed agreement with China commenced on 1 September 1998.

An Australian delegation met with the PRC officials in September and, as Senator Harradine suggested, were optimistic of reaching an agreement with the PRC. It did not occur at a meeting between the Ministry of Civil Affairs and the Australian embassy officials on 19 April this year. The ministry indicated that it was satisfied that Australian laws and regulations relating to adoptions were compatible with Chinese laws and regulations and that there was no significant impediment to the development of the agreement.

The ministry suggested that this take the form of an exchange of notes rather than a memorandum of understanding. Then, at the invitation of the MCA, officers of the Victorian Department of Human Services and of the Commonwealth's Attorney-General's Department met with MCA officials on 15 September 1999 to discuss the text of the agreement. In-principle agreement was reached on the text and the note and the drafts were exchanged. The MCA indicated, however, that the note would need to be cleared through the state council, which would take at least another three weeks.

Officers also met with officials of the China Centre for Adoption Affairs, which is under the umbrella of the MCA and responsible for day-to-day management of adoption matters. CCAA officials indicated that they had concerns about proposed medical clearance processes for adopted children. These pro cedural problems are not considered insurmountable by Australian officials but require consultation between Victoria, the states and territories before an agreed position can be reached in further discussion with the Chinese. Then I understand matters were further delayed because of the celebrations of the 50th anniversary in China and thus the matter is still not resolved. We believe there is a chance that it can be resolved by Minister Ruddock's visit in November, and he is hopeful that that is the case. (Time expired)

âMy question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. Given that the United Nations Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination found in March this year that the Native Title Act as amended is in breach of Australia's international obligations under the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination, isn't it both factually incorrect and misleading of the minister to post on his web site a fact sheet headed `Rebutting the myths', which states that Australia has a strong commitment to the principles contained in this convention?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Ridgeway for the question. Australia is proud of its record in honouring its international law obligations and is a signatory to a large number of human rights treaties, including the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. Australia is fully honouring its obligation to indigenous people in international law. Indigenous people in Australia enjoy the full range of civil and political rights of all Australians. The government was deeply disappointed with the report of the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination and their decision, which we believe is wrong.

answer.para: The committee failed to come to grips with the legal complexities of native title and ignored the extensive consultations that took place about the Native Title Act amendments and the comprehensive parliamentary debate. It absolutely ignored them. The amendments actually solved problems of uncertainty created by the original act and subsequent judicial decisions and forged a workable balance between indigenous people, pastoralists and other interested parties. Nevertheless, the committee's decision in August to further examine Australia in the context of its normal consideration of Australia's periodic reports under the CERD convention is sensible and should contribute to more constructive dialogue. I note also that the committee is no longer planning a visit to Australia.

The government is most concerned to address the socioeconomic disadvantages faced by indigenous people by implementing a large number of practical programs to improve the health, housing, education and employment opportunities of indigenous people in Australia. That is also on my web site. Also on my web site is the statement that the Commonwealth is spending on indigenous specific programs in 1999-2000 more funds than everâ$2.2 billion are going into this program. The government is doing an enormous amount. Senator Ridgeway asked me yesterday about self-determination in relation to indigenous people. I note that, four days ago, Elaine McKeon, an outstanding indigenous Australian, said from Cloncurry that the concept of self-determination to her meant:
I think that real self-determination comes when you are able to initiate something yourself and get that support, especially when it's going to mean real benefits for your people.

For a United Nations committee to make a determination in this regard is far removed from what people on the ground believe. The inappropriateness of the term `self-determination' in the domestic context is self-evident in any suggestion of sovereign self-government being relevant or applicable anywhere in Australia, whether it be in the Torres Strait, Cape York, the Kimberley, Arnhem Land, the Pitjantjatjara lands, or elsewhere.

I have no doubt that, when the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination fully understands what an enormous amount we are doing for the indigenous people of this country, they will reconsider their position. At all times we have honoured our obligations to indigenous people in international law, and we will continue to do so. We do not resile from that. We have taken an active interest in what the CERD committee has determined, and we have tried to explain to them that their original decision was not based on fact. We will be happy to do that should they come back to us at a future date. The position with the CERD committee is that it is still in the determination stage and no final decision has been reached. We will have to await that outcome.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), to questions without notice asked by Senator Cook and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) today, relating to magnetic resonance imaging services.

The government have tried to deflect attention from this matter; they have tried to cover up the issues at stake in this matter for 18 months. We have been pursuing this and pursuing this. But the minister continues to mislead about his involvement in this issue and he continues to mislead about the involvement of his ministerial office. Only today we had another example of why it is inappropriate for the minister to remain in his place and have control over an investigation of this matter. Minister Wooldridge went on ABC radio this morning and, in answer to a question about when the investigation took place, he said:

Last December the Health Insurance Commission received information from an anonymous source, which seemed to be well placed, that there were false statements in documents lodged with us in relation to the MRI applications. Upon receipt of that material I commenced the investigation.

So the minister was directly misleading the public by claiming that he initiated the investigation when the departmental officers have said all along that it was done by the HIC in relation to complaints they received. Clearly, this minister is still trying to put his spin on it, is still trying to put in place damage control and is still misleading the public. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âToday we are talking about a claim by the oppositionâyet again not substantiatedâthat somehow the Minister for Health and Aged Care has fiddled the books in terms of allowing people to order MRI scanners. It is just outrageous to think that the opposition can continually come into both chambers of this parliament and make unsubstantiated claims about ministerial involvement in something that is crooked.

speech.para: What the opposition have failed to spell out in categorical terms is that the claim that they are making is that somehow Minister Wooldridge was the source of the information givenâand Senator Evans nods. Thank you very much, Senator Evans. That is exactly the point you are raising: that Dr Wooldridge was the person who advised the radiologists to order the machines. Why doesn't the opposition come clean? Why don't they spell it out? That is really what they are claiming.

The previous Labor government failed the people of Australia miserably in creating accessibility to MRI technology. The Labor government made it so restrictive that it was not only hard to get if they wanted it but also prohibitive in terms of cost. People would have to wait months and months to get a scan or pay an enormous amount of money. And here we have the Labor opposition yet again poking at the government for taking the initiative to make sure that MRI scans are more readily available. But worse than that, they claim that the minister has done something illegal and improper. That is completely and utterly wrong. Such a claim is absolutely and utterly indefensible. The minister has acted with complete and utter propriety in this matter. He knows that there has been a question and he has sought to resolve the issue. That is the important thing.

No doctors can complain if they fall into the net of the new regulations that Minister Wooldridge is putting into place because, let's face it, doctors with machines operating or on order that are affected by this regulation have no reason whatsoever to complain. They took their own counsel and claimed to order machines with irrevocable contracts without any knowledge that the government would agree to allow Medicare benefits for services for those machines. So no-one can complain about it. For the opposition to come in here and suggest that Minister Wooldridge personally has somehow done something illegal is just absolutely and utterly objectionable and indefensible.

As I say, the fact of the matter remains that the decision was announced on 12 May 1998 as part of the 1998 budget. Last Friday the minister received a minute from the Managing Director of the HIC advising him that 111 MRI machines have now been notified to the commission. Of these, 59 were in place on 12 May 1998âthe date of the 1998 budgetâand 52 were claimed to be on order that day. No fewer than 13 of the machines claimed to be on order last May were advised to the HIC in the fortnight before the cut-off on 11 October this yearâthat is, in the last week or so, 13 radiologists remembered that they had spent $3 million on an MRI machine 18 months ago. That is pretty remarkable. No-one would disagree with that being a pretty remarkable thing. But the point of the matter is that the minister has sought to do something about it. For the opposition to come in here and claim that the minister has not done anything about it, is just simply and utterly wrong.

The interim measure will ensure that an advantage does not accrue to any person who may have taken advantage of backdating of a contract, a non-binding contract or any form of inside knowledge as a result of the negotiation process to order a machine before 12 May. That regulation will take effect on 1 November to ensure that people who have scans booked over the next fortnight at machines that will no longer be eligible for benefit will not be disadvantaged. That also applies to people in the country. Therefore, what the minister is trying to do is to ensureâin the total distortion of this argument put by the oppositionâthat the people who seek to get the scans and who are being given the scans are not the ones disadvantaged as they were under Labor. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI will pick up on the comments of the previous speaker, Senator Knowles, and add some further remarks. talk.start.para: âWhat a lot of nonsense all that was from Senator Forshaw and Senator Evans. speech.para: Let us look at what MRI is. MRI is magnetic resonance imaging. talk.start.para: âI seek leave to make a three-minute statement before asking that general business notice of motion No. 329 be taken as formal.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI wish to make some brief comments about the notice of motion that was given by three senatorsâmyself, Senator Bourne and Senator Payne. All three of us are members of the all-party parliamentary group on population and development. It seemed appropriate to move a motion to note that 12 October 1999 marked the day the population of this world was judged to have reached six billion people. We also thought that, as well as recognising the fact that we now have six billion people in this world, it is important to recognise the sorts of pressures on, and consequences of, a world of six billion people.

speech.para: First of all, I think we should celebrate it. It is an extremely amazing achievement that this world can now claim six billion people. That means that over this century there has been an amazing increase in the number of people who have survived and survived through to adulthood and enjoyed good health in their lifetimes. We also acknowledge though that, with that kind of population, we do need to look at the impact of uncontrollable population expansion. I am not arguing that it is uncontrollable at this time, but we need to recognise that uncontrollable population expansion will lead to increasing pressure on the world, particularly serious environmental and social problems.

Our notice of motion recognises the need of respect for cultural sensibilities, calls for a realistic approach to family planning, including access to information on family planning, and emphasises that the issues of population and development are interconnected. It has taken many years for women to argue that the capacity to have childrenâwhich is the particular responsibility of womenâneeds to be associated with the significant questions of economic development and environmental development in this world. That is why the Cairo achievements of 1994 were so important: at last concerns about population, which were up until then very much seen as women's concerns and of a minor nature, were finally seen as critical for this world's sustainable development.

In particular, I think the most important thing about a population of this size is the unfair distribution of this world's resources. Many of those six billion people do not have access to clean water, adequate food or reasonable housing, health or education. It is not just a matter of the size of the population in this world; it is a matter of the equity of the distribution of resources, so that everyone of those six billion people can expect to live a decent human life. At the moment, millions and billions of people in the developing world do not have the same claim on the world's resources as do people in the Western world. I believe it is a very important notice of motion. I thank the Senate for this opportunity to address it today. I ask that notice of motion No. 329 be taken as formal.

talk.start.para: âIs there any objection to notice of motion No. 329 being taken as formal?
âI seek leave to make a three-minute statement.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âThe policy issues relating to this matter deserve extensive and informed debate, not a truncated debate. If this notice of motion goes through, our successors in this Senate in 50 years time will look back on us as being demographic curiosities because it is based on a false assumption. The false assumption is that, as the notice of motion states, there is uncontrollable population growth, whereas, in fact, we are now well and truly in the demographic transition fromâas people call itâpopulation explosion to population implosion. Even the United Nations population division now indicatesâand the figures have been revised again; the UN is continually resizing them downâthat in the middle of next century there will be, in the low variant, 7.3 billion, and then, in actual numbers, population will decline. Professor Jack Caldwell, I notice, says it will decline to about four billion people.

speech.para: Unless we get this right, one of the problems is that we are going to put fear where fear is not appropriate. People are acting illogically because fear is surrounding this particular debate. They say that population increases the problem. Their fatal diagnosis is that people growth in developing countries is the problem and that population control is the solution. That diagnosis is deceptive, simplistic and distracts attention from the real problems and their solutions. The fertility of poor women in developing countries has been made the scapegoat for a range of problems from environmental damage to famine. The primary cause of these problems of course is war, political instability and man's inhumanity to manâinjustice.

An unhealthy fixation on population control is economically and socially naive and dangerous. It diverts the attention and efforts of governments in both the developed and developing world away from the real and pressing measures required. I am happy and really desirous of a genuinely informed debate on that subject. I am afraid the debate in the House of Representatives was far from informed.

talk.start.para: âIs there any objection to notice of motion No. 329 being declared formal? There is an objection.
âI ask that general business notice of motion No. 334, standing in my name for today and relating to the world's population reaching six billion, be taken as a formal motion.

speech.para: Leave not granted.

talk.start.para: âPursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

speech.para: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Brown moving a motion relating to the conduct of business of the Senate, namely, a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion no. 334.
I will read that motion to the Senate. It is:
That the Senate:
(a) notes that the Earth's populationâ

By the way, can I note for Hansard here that, as far as I am concerned, the earth is spelt with a capital e and not a small e. In the English language, every other planet gets a capital letter, and so should the one we live on. Let me continue:
(a) notes that the Earth's population will reach six billion during October 1999;
(b) recognises that the 20th century began with 1.6 billion and will end with 6.1 billion;
(c) understands that there may be as many as 10 to 14 billion people depending on the planet's finite resources during the 21st century; and
(d) calls for Australia to establish a global population policy.

The world has seen, through this century, on those figures, unprecedented growth of a large and wonderful mammal, homo sapiens, which is at the end of the century taking 40 per cent of the available food stock and which is, according to modest projections from the United Nations, going to continue to grow in population numbers to an estimated 8.9 billion by the year 2050âthat is, in the lifetimes of most Australians now in their primary or high school years.

The problem is compounded because, as Senator Crowley said a moment ago, there is an enormous imbalance between the haves and have-nots in the consumption of resources. This is true particularly of the wealthiest people in the worldâin fact, we have figures that show that some 350 individuals on this planet own as much as the world's poorest one billion or two billion people. It is an extraordinarily out of kilter human community we live in and, if we are going to put things to rights, we are going to have to extend to other people outside our country, I believe, part of the fair go that Senator Harradine was talking about that we have within our own country. It is certainly not the case at the moment. The reason for the urgency of this motion is that it is time that, at the national level, we instituted a population policy which tries to reach out to the rest of the world as well as looks at what we have in this country, in the interests of future generations everywhere, including future generations of Australians.

We are still far from achieving a goal of fairness. Let me read from the United Nations publication, noting there are six billion people in the world. It says, for example, of the health life of women in the poorer world, that more than half of the days lost in their reproductive years are related to pregnancy, complications of pregnancy and reproductive disorders. Three hundred and fifty million women, nearly one-third of all women of reproductive age, in developing countries still do not have access to a range of modern, safe and acceptable methods of family planning, and 120 million more women would use family planning now if it were more widely available, better understood, supported by communities and families and backed by quality programs. In developing countries 585,000 women die each year as a result of pregnancy and many times that number of women suffer infection or injury. Seventy thousand lives are lost each year to unsafe abortions. Women are nearly two-thirds of the world's 960 million illiterates, and women and girls make up three-fifths of the world's poor. Part of the response by the United Nations is not just to afford education and alternatives, including the lowly condom, to those people who would want to have that option available to them but to ensure that men also are aware of the advantages of being able to make decisions for themselves.

Our national government has instituted many of the policies we would like to see worldwide, including legislation for equality, good health and opportunity to access reproductive choices. Surely we ought to be extending that domestic largesse to the rest of the world in the interests of everybody to come, as well as living space on this planet for our 30 million fellow creatures. I seek the Senate's support to go on to debate this issue for its sheer importance. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI oppose the suspension of standing orders for the very reason that we do need an extensive, informed debate, and we cannot have an extensive, informed debate by suggesting that a matter can be taken as formal and then voted upon or by a truncated debate in a situation like this, when many of our colleagues do not even know what was going on because they are in committees. Let us have it out at one particular stage in a period of time, say, general business time, when we all know what we are talking about. speech.para: Senator Brown talks about the effects of population. The figures that he gave to the Senate are somewhat wrong, but we will deal with those at some other stage. Furthermore, he calls on Australia to establish a global population policy. That suggests it would be an entirely cleaner place if there were less Indians in the world, if there were less Asians in the world, if there were less Africans in the world? We are going out the back door in Australia, and so are large numbers of other countries. One particular speaker in the House of Representatives debate talked about Italy and how long it would take for it to double its population. But I want to indicate that we do need such a debate. You mentioned health. Look, the UNFPA is after your money. The problem is that the money goes there and it is not going to the real causes of maternal mortality. The vast majority of maternal deaths are directly attributed to four major causes: haemorrhage, infection, hypertension and obstructed labour. Furthermore, the danger is that, if you raise the fear of overpopulation, you are definitely subscribing to human rights violations. talk.start.para: âThat is why we need a debateâ
âWe do need a debate. Furthermore, we have Mr Hollis in the other house saying:

speech.para: I also believe that many religions, especially the Catholic faith, have much to answer for. It is somewhat ironic that men, often elderly, in dresses are dictating to women how their bodies should be used.

talk.start.para: âThe opposition does not support the suspension of standing orders to debate this motion. I think it is important, however, to emphasise to the chamber that this is of course an issue of the utmost importance.
âThen let's debate it.

âNo, but the issue itself is of the utmost importance. The problem arises in terms of the wording of the particular motion that we have before us today, Senator Brown. The opposition indicated its support for motion No. 329 on the same question, which was not given formality. âSo why aren't we debating that?

subdebateinfo.title: AFTA-CER Ministerial Meetings and Bilateral Visit to Japan

talk.start.para: âI table a statement by the Minister for Trade on the AFTA-CER ministerial meetings and on a bilateral visit to Japan and I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The statement read as followsâ

para.inline: STATEMENT BY MR VAILE ON THE AFTA-CER MINISTERIAL MEETING AND HIS VISIT TO JAPAN (1-5 OCTOBER 1999)

speech.para: I wish to inform the House of the outcomes of my visit at the beginning of this month to Singapore and then Japan. Singapore is Australia's eighth largest market taking around 6 per cent of our exports. As a group, the ten countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) account for over 12 per cent of Australia's exports. Japan is, of course, our largest export market taking almost 20 per cent of total exports.

Both visits allowed me to continue our Government's efforts to win greater access to regional markets for Australian exporters, and also to advance our agenda on the forthcoming WTO meeting in Seattle.

On 1 October, I attended the 4th AFTA-CER Meeting in Singapore between ASEAN Ministers and Ministers from the Closer Economic Relations (CER) countriesâAustralia and New Zealand. I went there with three key objectives: (i) to produce a strong, unambiguous statement of support by ASEAN for the launch of a new WTO round; (ii) to expand the useful trade facilitation work that has been done under the AFTA-CER linkage; and (iii) to accelerate the removal of tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade within our region.

Mr Speaker, despite some speculation that events in East Timor might detract from Australia's capacity to pursue our trade interests at the AFTA-CER meeting, I am pleased to report that the meeting delivered some significant breakthroughs for Australia.

Most importantly, Ministers agreed that a high-level taskforce will be established to examine the feasibility of an AFTA-CER free trade area by 2010. This process has the potential to achieve substantial improvements in market access for Australian exporters. The taskforce will report to Ministers in twelve months time on the benefits and costs involved in a possible free trade agreement. Independent studies suggest billions of dollars in additional income to Australia from free trade between ASEAN and the CER countries.

The Australian Industry Group has congratulated the Government on this "ground breaking announcement" and I look forward to pursuing our agenda when I again meet Minister Yeo from Singapore and Dr Supachai from Thailand later this month. This initiative demonstrates this Government's pragmatic approach to free trade agreements where they can deliver substantial benefits to Australia consistent with our APEC and WTO goals. Members should recall that the Labor Party in Government always liked to parade their multilateral credentials while criticising any discussion of FTAs. Now, all of a sudden, Senator Cook and the member for Fraser have discovered what they call the "free trade agreement game". But in Government, Labor totally neglected this policy track despite the fact that, as Senator Cook himself concedes, the Uruguay Round dragged on for far too long under Labor. This Government is pressing for a short, sharp (3 year) WTO round coming out of the Seattle WTO meeting. At the same time, we stand ready to participate in meaningful efforts for freer trade with key bilateral and regional trading partners.
Mr Speaker, there were some other important outcomes from the Singapore meeting.

. AFTA-CER's practical work on streamlining standards, customs procedures and quarantine cooperation provides direct benefits to Australian business. The Singapore meeting witnessed the amendment of the MOU on Standards and Conformance to include Burma, Cambodia and Laos. This agreement is already reducing production costs for Australian business by encouraging the adoption of international standards.

. Ministers also agreed to trial the Australian developed SANCRT electronic health certificate system for trade in agricultural products and to build closer links between the quarantine services of ASEAN and CER. These measures will reduce the costs to exporters through more timely processing of import documentation and more common approaches on standards, practices and procedures.

. In addition, I highlighted the useful opportunity for regional cooperation in the automotive sector presented by the ASEAN automotive study being undertaken by the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council with Australian support.

While in Singapore, I also launched a new promotion to boost the export of chilled Australian pork. The strong demand for Australian chilled pork in Singapore has already seen imports increase from 45 tonnes per day in July to 70 tonnes per day at present. And wrapping up a busy program, I presented export awards to two outstanding Australian companies at a dinner organised by the Singapore Australian Business Council. These awards to the Cox Group for its design of Stage 1 of the new Singapore Convention and Exhibition Centre and to Geraldton Boat Builders for the supply of 20 vessels to the Singapore Police Coast Guard drew attention to Australia's expertise in high-value services and high-value manufactures. I want to congratulate both companies on their achievements.

The Japanese leg of my trip provided the opportunity to extend Australia's dialogue with our largest trading partner in the run-up to the Seattle WTO meeting and to have productive meetings with key business interests and Japanese importers of Australian products.

Despite the fact that my visit coincided with a major Cabinet reshuffle by Prime Minister Obuchi, I had the opportunity to meet both the outgoing MITI Minister, Mr Yosano, and the incoming Minister, Mr Fukaya.

These very useful meetings allowed me to highlight Australia's desire to work closely with Japan in areas of common interest in the new WTO round whilst making clear that we support a three-year round focused on core market access issues. While in Japan, I left a strong message that Australia expects Japan to play a proactive role in the WTO negotiations and that further liberalisation of Japanese markets for agricultural products is central to achieving credible results.

I took the opportunity to brief my Japanese counterparts on the proposed feasibility study on an AFTA-CER free trade area. We agreed to maintain contact on how both countries see developments surrounding free trade agreements in our region and to ensure that any initiatives are fully consistent with a strong rules-based system under the WTO.

I also met with Japanese business leaders which allowed me to pursue opportunities for Australian exporters, and to obtain a detailed update on Japan's economy and reform measures. The general picture to emerge was one of cautious optimism about economic recovery in Japan. But at the same time, my meetings with Mr Takashi Imai, the Chairman of Keidanren (Japan Federation of Economic Organisations) and other business leaders underscored the need for the Japanese Government to intensify economic reform to achieve a return to sustainable growth.

Along with my colleague the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, I was pleased to address an Austrade-sponsored seminar to promote Australian financial services. And in Osaka I officially launched Business Club Australia in the Kansai regionâan Austrade program designed to maximise Australian commercial opportunities in and around the Olympics next year.

Mr Speaker, this visit which centred on discussions with many of our key trading partners in Asia reaffirmed this Government's determination to work at all levels for Australian exportersâbuilding support for our goals in the WTO, taking our trade ties with our ASEAN partners into a new phase, and opening doors bilaterally for Australian firms.

I came away with a clear sense that Australia's trade relations in Asia are in very good shape. East Asia accounts for 52 per cent of our export earnings and includes seven of our top ten trading partners. I encountered widespread appreciation in both Singapore and Japan of the strength of the Australian economy and of how this Government's reform measures have made Australia more competitive. There was a recognition that Australia contributes to the prosperity and security of Asia; just as Asia contributes to the prosperity and security of Australia.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

I welcome the tabling of Minister Vaile's statement. The practice of ministers regularly informing the Senate of current issues in their portfolio is to be commended. The proper role of the Senate in such matters must be to scrutinise the statement, and that will be the basis of my remarks today. The first part of Minister Vaile's statement deals with the recent ASEAN Free Trade Agreement, CERâthat is, closer economic relationsâwith New Zealand and a meeting on the trade pact between Australia and New Zealand. The minister sets out what his objectives were for the meeting and how he went about meeting them. They are all good objectives, I have to say, although I note that this is the first time we have heard of any of them, and it would have been a little braver if the minister had actually stated them before he left Australia rather than when he came back home.

Labor welcomes the minister's work on an AFTA-CER trade agreement, but Minister Vaile's attempt to claim credit for inventing the wheel should not go unregarded. A few facts need to be made clear. The idea of an AFTA-CER trade agreement was first raised by Paul Keating in a speech in Thailand in April 1994, yet since the coalition came to power in 1996 the idea has been assigned to the backburner. So much so in fact that in a speech I made in 1997 I criticised the government for neglecting the issue and have done so on several occasions since. In a statement that has been tabled, Minister Vaile said:

Now, all of a sudden, Senator Cook and the member for Fraser have discovered what they call the "free trade agreement game" but in Government, Labor totally neglected this policy track despite the fact that, as Senator Cook himself concedes, the Uruguay Round dragged on for far too long under Labor.
We were one nation of about 100 in the world, and it was no fault of Australia's that the Uruguay Round dragged on too long.
To the charge, let me quote from the speech I made on 24 April 1997. Bear in mind as I do so that I have been accused of neglecting this issue. I said:
Let me give you a positive example of where the Government should be pursuing a more activist agenda in the national interest.

In 1994 the former Government proposed an initiative to bring CER and AFTA closer together. CER (Closer Economic Relations) with New Zealand is the only thing that approaches a trade bloc for Australia. AFTA covers the ASEAN Region and is a trade bloc with the objective of removing 90% of the Commonwealth External Preferential Tariff (CEPT) on industrial products by the year 2003.
In other words the ASEAN countries, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Brunei and the Philippines are removing protection between themselves in order to create an internal free-trade zone.

The Keating initiative started a series of talks to bring Australia and New Zealand into this process. At Government level these talks have . . . concentrated on dealing with "facilitation" issuesâthe sorting out of Customs arrangements and simplifying the red tape associated with market access and Sanitary and Phyto Sanitary regulations.

This is an initiative whose value is underestimated or overlooked in Australia. It is rarely referred to by the Minister yet it relates to opening up relations with our neighbouring economies, the Asian Tigers who are leaders in world economic growth, and who have in place some of the higher external tariffs to be found on industrial products anywhere.
What has to be acknowledged . . .

I then go on and talk about the role of the MTIA. My purpose in quoting that is to mark the spotâthat they were the words I said in 1997âand to reply to the allegation by the minister that Labor has neglected this process.

Let me go on referring to his statement. The government's decision to take up the AFTA-CER process more than five years after it was first proposed by Labor is due in large part to lobbying by the Australian Industry Group, formerly the MTIA, which has relentlessly pursued AFTA-CER on a business to business basis and through representations to Asian governments. Minister Vaile is right to thank the Australian Industry Group for their work on it for the same reason that a jockey might thank his horse after a race.

Labor welcomes the government's decision to pursue an AFTA-CER agreement. It can play an important role in further energising APEC and promoting its free-trade goals. However, we are still waiting for the phrase `Pacific 5' to fall from the minister's lips. I am referring, of course, to the mooted free-trade agreement between the United States, Singapore, Chile, New Zealand and Australia. Recent reports suggest that New Zealand has been the driving force behind this agreement, with enthusiasm from the other partners. In contrast, Australia has been dragging its heels all the way. If Minister Vaile is going to castigate me and Bob McMullan for our support of free-trade agreements, the least he can do is to tell us where he stands on P5âbefore it becomes P4.

To criticise Labor on this ground is hypocritical. Labor initiated the very agreement over which the minister is trying to rewrite history. Last month, during the Jiang Zemin visit, Kim Beazley proposed a China-Australia trade agreement. This would be an important bilateral trade initiative which would bring greater coherence to our flourishing relationship, push the APEC goals further and provide a means for harvesting some business and commercial benefit from our support for China's accession to the WTO. This is an important proposal. On today's performance, perhaps we will hear from the government about it when they claim the credit for putting it forward some time in the future, when the opportunity now available has largely been missed.

Of course, there is the overture from the United States, floated in February 1998, and the USTR's report to the President for an Australia-US trade pact. This was dismissed out of hand by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Alexander Downer, when Labor advocated exploring the proposal so its economic impact could be properly assessed. The pity for Minister Vaile is that the government has neglected possibilities for bilateral trade agreements and has just now discovered them. Labor has always been ahead of that game.

Minister Vaile also informed us of his recent meetings with Singaporean and Japanese government officials. He neglected to say, however, that the latest trade statistics, released just a few days before his departure, showed that, while Asian economic growth has returned, our exports to Asia remain flat. In fact, we exported less to our 10 most significant Asian trading partners in the first eight months of 1999 than we did over the first eight months of 1998. While Asian economies are going north, our trade balance with Asia is going south.

As I said at the outset, I welcome this report and look forward to hearing Minister Vaile's next report to parliament. Perhaps in that report he will not only give us a pleasant travelogue but also address some of the hard questions in his portfolio. He could start with the following. Firstly, figures just released show that in 1998 our exports of elaborately transformed manufactures fell in value by $868 million, the first fall in 20 years. Does this have anything to do with the fact that total Commonwealth expenditure on education, training and research has fallen from 2.99 per cent of GDP in Labor's last year of office to 2.53 per cent today?

Secondly, why are Australian manufacturing exports as a whole falling for the first time since 1981? Thirdly, the United States has just released a comprehensive statement on its strategy for the next round of WTO organisa tions. When will Australia release a similar statement setting out our goals and objectives for the WTO round, if it is kicked off in the November-December WTO meeting in Seattle this year? Fourthly, why does Australia now have its highest trade deficit, its highest current account deficit and its highest level of foreign liabilities ever? This is a fundamental question going to the heart of the economic performance of the Australian economy and, given international scrutiny of our trade deficit, current account deficit and foreign debt, obviously will militate against Australia's domestic economic performance in the future if there is not a positive program by the government to lift our trading performance and the competitiveness of the Australian nation. I look forward with keen interest to hearing Mark Vaile's answers to those questions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âI want to make some general comments at the commencement of the committee stage of the Stevedoring Levy (Collection) Amendment Bill 1999 . The major stevedore, P&O, is on the record as saying that it does not support the funding of these other initiativesâas distinct from the redundancies; that it will not seek funding for these other initiatives; and that it would prefer that these matters were not addressed by this particular method of funding and were therefore not financed by levy contribution. So almost 18 months after the announcement of the benchmarks and the alleged signing up of the playersâand there were only two, at that stage, of all the stevedores that signed up to the government's packageânothing has happened. Quite properly, Mr Anderson, in answer to a question on noticeâand Senator Macdonald referred to this again todayâraised the issue of what the effect of our amendment would be, suggesting that the issue we should pursue is the principle that the waterfront industry ought to pay for these reforms rather than the taxpayer. Of course, there is nothing wrong with that. Indeed, there is nothing preventing those who have signed up to the government's initiatives from paying for these reforms if they wish to pursue them or if the government can persuade them to do so. But what the government wants to do is to arrange for a borrowing capacity from MIFCo and then to compulsorily levy all stevedores so that those who want to use the initiativeâand I stress that only one at this stage has made an application and the other major has said it will notâcan do so. The government wants us to increase the borrowing capacity of MIFCo by $50 million so that some initiatives, as yet unknown, pursuant to guidelines as yet not established, can be approved and financed through this package.

The opposition has a significant problem with that. There is no way that this is proper accountability in the legislative process. If the government were genuine in pursuing this, they would have developed guidelines for funding and had certain initiatives that they wanted to fund. They would have established those stevedores who wish to have funding, they would have investigated projects and they would have been able to come to the Senateâor indeed to the House of Representatives when they put the bill before itâwith some concrete ideas of where these moneys were to be spent. We are talking about these issues more than a year after the original bill was carried. Have they got that? The answer, of course, is no. So in this case, we think it is apparent that, whatever the Senate has done in relation to the initiatives of the original bill, it has the opportunity to look at those in the light of the performance of the government.

In relation to the government's proposal to extend borrowings, we are not so dog in the manger as to say, `Let's do nothing.' We concede that there are certain commitments which require a borrowing guarantee increased from $250 million to $300 million. That is from evidence that we were able to ascertain not from the second reading speech, not from the minister's answer to questions on notice or anything put in here, but from questions asked of officers of the department, who were able to give us accurate figures. Dr Feeney and Mr Brocklebank gave us information on the borrowing needs and the consequences of not increasing that borrowing capacity. There are no consequences in terms of the original loan arrangements entered into by MIFCo if our amendment is carriedâthat is, to limit the borrowing to $300 million, not to the $350 million that the government is seeking.

We believeâif I can speak generally at this stageâthat there is every reason to support our amendments, and carriage of the bill with those amendments will not disadvantage MIFCo or the stevedores. As for any known or contemplated project, if Patrick have a need for $1 million, one would have thought, given that they are not passing on the savings that they have made through the reforms which have been financed by this package, that perhaps they ought to pay for that themselves. There is no reason why those improvements should be imposed on other stevedores, thereby keeping stevedoring charges high for the users of Australian ports, by allowing the extension that the government proposes to the bill. At this stage, I will leave it there. Obviously, I would be interested to hear some comments on that. I have some questions to ask. Perhaps the minister could respond now, before I move the amendments.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 October, on motion by Senator Patterson:
That this bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Carr had moved by way of amendment:
At the end of the motion, add "but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a) using the important issue of literacy in a cynical political fashion; and
(b) failing to provide government schools with additional resources in line with its increased expenditure for the non-government sector".

talk.start.para: âThe States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999 amends the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1996 to give effect to initiatives announced in the context of this year's budget. The provisions of this bill include $36.3 million in the year 2000 for increased funding under the Literacy and Numeracy Program to improve literacy and numeracy outcomes for students, particularly in the middle years of schooling. It also includes $26.4 million to extend funding for the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools Strategy for the year 2000; the continuation of previous capital funding arrangements for non-government schools; and, more importantly, contingency funding for struggling non-government schools in the transition to the new system of funding for those non-government schools.

speech.para: In March 1997, the Commonwealth, state and territory education ministers agreed to a national literacy goal that every child leaving primary school should be numerate and able to read, write and spell at an appropriate level. This is a goal that not only most of us here but also those in the community would agree with. The ministers also agreed to the adoption of a national literacy plan. There are two strands to the Commonwealth funding for literacy programs which give effect to the plan. These are grants to schools to foster literacy and numeracy development, targeting educationally disadvantaged students, and grants for national literacy and numeracy strategies and projects.

The proposed legislation will increase funding generally for the literacy and numeracy plan and it will specifically support new initiatives that target students in the middle years of schoolingâstudents in upper primary and secondary school through to year 10. The additional capital grants funding for non-government schools and the additional funding for short-term emergency assistance are also for non-government schools. It is a contingency fund to assist those schools which will receive increased funding under the new system announced in the 1999-2000 budget. That outline of the bill may sound okay for those who know very little about what is happening in the primary-secondary school system, but the motion moved by Senator Carr in the Senate last week condemns this government for using the important issue of literacy in a cynical and political fashion and for failing to provide government schools with additional resources in line with its increased expenditure for the non-government sector.

Let us now turn to what is, in fact, going to be the new system of funding for non-government schools. Of course, this bill provides contingency funding for those struggling non-government schools. In Dr Kemp's statement on choice and equity in funding arrangements for non-government schools in the years 2001-04âthe minister has hit the headlines this week for his most shameful and incompetent attempt to realign the higher education sector to a position where most Australians do not want it to go and would never agree to the position on which he has insistedâhe claimed, at page 1, that the system will provide high levels of funding for the neediest school communities, that the government is committed to needs based funding for non-government schools and that a more equitable funding mechanism was sought. At page 2 the minister said that the government had decided that funding to non-government schools serving the neediest of communities should be significantly increased.

Given this level of rhetoric, it seems reasonable to assume that the schools that are the most likely to benefit from the new arrangementsâas we have been told in estimatesâwill be those that currently have the lowest levels of resources. It is something of a shock when you analyse the figures very carefully to find that, in fact, it is exactly the opposite. The schools which gain most from the new model will be those schools which are currently considered the most wealthy. Let me provide you with one example. One of the schools that will benefit is believed to be the School of Total Education in Warwick, Queensland. This school currently has a budget of $1 million for its 115 students, largely as a result of corporate sponsorship. This works out to be nearly $8,700 per student in a school of only 115 students, compared with about $5,200 in government schools. Under the new funding arrangements, this school is apparently set to gain in the region of an additional $3,000 per studentâtaking it to well over twice the resourcing level of a government school. Those on the government side may well argue this is an extreme example, and it is, but it is one example under this new funding model.

The new model, which is called the SES modelâthe socioeconomic status modelâprovides funding for the non-government school sector and was announced as part of this year's budget. The new funding arrangements are due to be introduced from 2001âhence the contingency funding in this billâand they will be phased in over four years so that any increases will occur at 25 per cent per year from 2001 to 2004. Non-government schools are currently funded on the basis of a funding model called the education resources index. We have known for a long time that there have been inadequacies in this funding arrangement. There have been many comments about a need to actually revise and review this funding arrangement. However, we in the Labor Party believe that this is not the way to deal with it; this is not the answer. It is not adequate. It also targets only a certain range of schools in the non-government sector. The education resources index measures the financial capacity of the school. The current method includes such things as fees and schools' income from bequests, reserves and so on. In effect, the current system attempts to measure the total financial resources of the school and, therefore, the remaining needs which the government should meet.

It is claimed that the current system is not working and that there are widespread discrepancies between schools with the same ERIâthe education resources index. In part this is because, some would say, in the past NGSs have become very good at manipulating their figures, distorting the ERI and therefore maximising government funding. However, there has been no attempt by this government to analyse what the problems were or to find better ways of measuring school wealth. The research carried out by DETYA was, I believe, controlled by the non-government sector and driven by their concerns rather than by genuine research criteria.

The new funding model, which I do not have time to outline, in effect measures the financial resources of the student community attending a particular school. It is actually based on a random sample of 100 addresses in that area which are then coded against ABS statisticsâa fairly complicated process. In fact, what you actually do is measure the financial resources of the student community attending the particular school, rather than or ignoring the financial capacity of the school.

So what are the problems with the current proposal? Firstly, only a few of the non-government sector schools were included. Catholic schools, which represent over 60 per cent of private schools, will not have their SES assessed but have been deemed to be at a certain level as part of a settlement between that sector and this government. Wealthy schools will not have their funding reduced. Even schools which are operating at twice the level, or more, of resources in government schools are guaranteed $597 per primary student and $829 per secondary student per year. No school will be worse off than at present. If their SES puts them below the current funding, then the SES will be ignored.

Even DETYA admits that only about 750 of the 2,500 non-government sector schools will actually have their funding determined by their SES. All others will either be exempt or funded above the SES. This means in effect more money for the private schools. Between now and 2003, private schools will receive an increase in recurrent funding of $755.2 million; that is, about $418 million for Catholic schools and $338.2 million for other private schools. Government schools will in fact receive no increase.

When the coalition came to power in 1996, government schools got 54c of operational expenditure for every dollar spent on private schools; by 2003, they will get only 42c. Even the wealthiest primary schools will get about $72 more per student under the proposed scheme. The SES scheme is not a needs based model. It will create less equity, not more. The proposal is based upon creating equity of federal government inputs, not equity of resource provision. Schools will get the money regardless of their own financial situation. The school can then add on its own resources, whether they are accumulated reserves, bequests or even greater fundraising capacity, to advantage its students over those from similar backgrounds attending less advantaged schools.

This system is designed to undermine the public education system. Private schools will be able to lower their fees and attract even more students. It will encourage private schools to open campuses in less well off suburbs, cream off the best students from government schools and then claim a lower SES rating for all their students. Low fee private schools will get almost the same money as government schools. Wealthy private schools will be encouraged to poach the highest achieving students from government schools through scholarships. They will be able to keep expanding because they will always produce apparently better outcomes than schools that are not able to select who they teach. All this will mean that government schools will be robbed of even more by the increase in the EBAâthe enrolment benchmark adjustment.

This scheme is intended to ensure that public provision is basic. Any parent with aspirations that their child receive quality will be forced to pay, either through fees to private schools or through contributions to those government schools which are seeking to compete.

Let us have a look at the status of education, particularly in secondary schools, since 1996. We have had four years of hostility from the Howard government towards public education. In 1996, $350 million was cut from public education and private schooling was deregulated.

However, the press release goes on. I would encourage the chamber and the public to read the contents of the report closely. It does not, in my opinion, provide an upbeat view of national competition policy. The report recognises that communities in regional and rural Australia are receiving a range of negative impacts, and the aspects of those range across a number of influences. However, it says that national competition policy is only one of those. The report says that the government cannot control these long-term influences, that these are primarily responsible for the declining share of primary industries and that national competition policy is by and large used as a scapegoat. The Treasurer's press release seems to completely miss out these elements of the commission's report, which really go to the heart of it and need to be made clear.
