talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to address an area of particular ongoing interest to me and one on which there are regular contributions by various senators in the chamber: the challenges that face people living in rural and regional Australia. Specifically, I want to look at some of the issues that confront rural families.

speech.para: This government, since its election and for many decades before that, has had a longstanding commitment to families who live in rural and regional Australia, most recently developed through the launching of a National Families Strategy. That announcement, which was partly in response to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, included the establishment of a new Marriage and Family Council. The strategy will focus on the different life stages of families and their different needs through those stages.

Announcements were made in the last budget of a pilot voucher scheme for marriage and relationship education services and also for men and relationship education services. These are very important developments and I think are a valuable step forward in an important policy area. I receive a huge number of constituent inquiries in relation to issues of family breakdown, domestic violence, family law and a range of the other concerns that surround this area. Those constituents of mine are members of families of every size and description, from the most traditional to the so-called unorthodox. They have concerns which impact significantly on their day-to-day lives.

Some of the strongest concerns that are expressed come from families living in rural and regional areas of New South Wales, in relation to the particular challenges they face. Recently, I addressed questions of the challenges faced by people in those areas. For example, I have touched on the challenges facing rural women in accessing new technologies and the impact of mental health difficulties on young Australians, amongst other things. But they are only some of the issues that concern many Australians, espe cially those who are not in the metropolitan areas, on a daily basis. These issues challenge those who live outside metropolitan areas in particular ways that often differ from the challenges faced by their counterparts who do live in metropolitan areas.

The differences between the situation of families in regional as opposed to metropolitan New South Wales are significant. There are statistical indicators of the income and expenditure differences between families in rural and regional Australia and those in metropolitan locations which are indicative of that. For example, according to the ABS figures of 1993-94, metropolitan households earn, on average, $783.14 while those outside the metropolitan areas earn $614.71. Of those living outside metropolitan locations, a total of 16.7 per cent of their income is derived from government pensions and allowances, compared with 11.4 per cent for those living in the cities.

On average, households in metropolitan areas spend $83.94 per week on recreation, compared with $71 in rural areas. Households in rural areas spend markedly less on personal care and less on clothing and footwear. So the picture that emerges from those figures is of two households: one in, say, suburban Sydney earning more than their regional counterpart in Albury or Armidale in New South Wales, spending more of that income on relaxing, looking after themselves and being less reliant on government for financial support. I recognise that these figures are averages, but it is not necessarily a welcome comparison that they provide.

The challenges that families do face in non-metropolitan areas of New South Wales are not always financial. The concerns of many of my constituents who come to me relate to less tangible issues, such as their quality of life. They relate to matters like access to quality health care in rural and regional New South Wales. This is an issue that has received significant attention through the launch of a new plan to improve rural health across Australia.

As senators may be aware, this plan, Healthy Horizons, is a partnership between the Commonwealth, the states, the territories and the National Rural Health Alliance. It includes commitments to improve highest health priorities, concentrating effort where health is poor; to improve the health of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people living in rural, regional and remote Australia; to maintain a skilled and responsive health work force; to develop needs based, flexible funding arrangements for rural, regional and remote Australia; and to achieve recognition of rural, regional and remote health as an important component of the Australian health system.

In that area, one of the particular issues raised is access to doctors. I have heard many stories of the problems faced by communities that do not have the same access to doctors as those in the cities and which are often not even able to attract a single practitioner to their towns. There are real challenges in attracting and retaining GPs in rural communities. At present, about half the general practitioners who move to rural areas remain there for less than two years. The challenge in that area is partially to do with the perception that is held by doctors themselves about living and working outside the cities.

There is now some support available to assist in addressing the problem. In the last budget there was funding in excess of $43 million over four years for retention payments to encourage doctors to stay in rural and remote areas. There has been funding directed towards medical education, including the establishment of a medical school at James Cook University and a clinical school at Charles Sturt University at Wagga Wagga.

The University of Southern Cross, though, has also proposed the establishment of a postgraduate medical school at their campus in Lismore, New South Wales. Their aim is to address the shortage of doctors in northern New South Wales, where the problem is especially acute. In towns like Kyogle, which is just west of Lismore, there are five local GPs, but they are all about the same age. They are all about to retire, leaving the town's population quite probably without access to a GP.

The University of Southern Cross suggests that the problem can be approached by training local people and encouraging them to stay in their local community, and it is an approach of which I am particularly supportive. That, in conjunction with other initiatives, like assisting rural medical students with their studies, is one answer to the complex question of addressing this issue on a long-term basis.

There is also the significant issue of family breakdown. It is difficult in any circumstance but often, if it occurs in rural areas to farming families, the problems are exacerbated. Recently while visiting a New South Wales rural town, I met with the coordinator of the local women's refuge. We talked about some of the problems that she and her workers faced every day. It is not surprising that you would hear someone like that speak about problems associated with mental illness, drug and alcohol abuse or domestic violence. But what is really interesting is the way those problems manifest in a small town. For example, anonymity and confidentiality is one of the most important safety concerns for women who enter a refuge. But in this town, the presence and location of the refuge is very well known. She told me a story of a man who arrived in town on a train, walked to the taxi rank and asked to be taken to the refuge. It is not surprising that the taxi driver knew the location of the refuge but what is of concern is that the gentleman could simply be delivered to the front door of the refuge, and it becomes a much more significant problem than you would otherwise expect. The location of refuges in cities is not a secret, but issues of confidentiality and safety are perhaps a little easier to manage among a larger and more diverse population. There are real safety and ongoing effectiveness concerns about the operation of those organisations in rural Australia.

I have also been approached about intergenerational farming and property settlement in the case of family breakdown, particularly in relation to a husband and wife who are divorcing and have to look at a very complex property settlement. The concern particularly raised with me recently was about the property in question having been in the ownership of a family for several generations. A family breakdown or divorce is a difficult circumstance to endure at best, but when compounded by the threat of losing your property, held and looked after by your parents and your grandparents before them, the problems are heightened. It is a complex property situation that many city residents may find hard to relate to. Balancing the contributions of both partners in a relationship with an eye to generational contributions is fraught with difficulty.

We have sought to address the broader issue of intergenerational farming outside of circumstances involving family breakdown, and the Retirement Assistance for Farmers scheme, part of the Agriculture Advancing Australia initiative, allows older farmers to gift up to $500,000 of farm assets to younger generations and to access the age pension. But it is a much broader issue than that.

Earlier this year the Attorney-General announced plans to implement family law reforms to ensure greater certainty in property settlements, to allow people to make binding financial arrangements about their property before marriage, during marriage and on the dissolution of marriage. It is the hope of many of us who have paid particular attention to this issue, either through personal involvement or otherwise, that legislation introduced as a result of that announcement might improve the situation.

There are other issues of significant concern to rural families: finding jobs for their children in small towns; arresting the alarming rate of youth suicide, particularly amongst young men; and dealing with new emerging technologies and their impact. But the sentiment most often expressed to me by families in these areas is their commitment to solving these problems as a family and as a community.

Anyone who has ever spent much time in a small town or regional area will be aware of the strong sense of community. While it may have been eroded by contemporary developments, there still remains a sense of assurance which is not always visible in metropolitan areas. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âTonight I rise to pay tribute to the Northern Territory Breast Cancer Voice. This group is part of an emerging network of similar organisations around Australia dedicated to improving the lives of women with breast cancer. These organisations, run by volunteers who are breast cancer survivors, play a vital advocacy role for women diagnosed with breast cancer. Tonight I would like to draw particular attention to the efforts of the Northern Territory Breast Cancer Voice in raising awareness of this significant women's health issue in the lead-up to National Breast Cancer Day on 25 October.

speech.para: The significance of breast cancer cannot be denied. Given that an Australian woman born today has a one-in-11 chance of developing breast cancer, it is an issue that can no longer be ignored or underestimated. If we exclude non-melanoma skin cancers, breast cancer remains the most frequently diagnosed cancer for Australian women. It is also, of course, the major cause of cancer death among women in Australia.

While these statistics are rather sobering, tonight I want to highlight the positive efforts of women involved in advocacy agencies around the country. These organisations are formidable advocates on issues affecting the lives of women with breast cancer, and their efforts are an inspiring example of what women can achieve when they act collectively on issues that affect them uniquely as women.

I am proud to stand here and support the Northern Territory Breast Cancer Voice. I have followed their achievements with a great deal of admiration since they began in August of last year. During this month, the Northern Territory Breast Cancer Voice is coordinating several events to raise awareness of breast cancer which I believe are worthy of acknowledgment. Last Sunday, the planting of a `field of women' in Darwinâcoinciding with a similar activity at the MCGâprovided an opportunity to reflect on the meaning of breast cancer, both for those women living with the diagnosis and for those people who have been affected by the death from breast cancer of a friend, a family member or a patient.

The Northern Territory Breast Cancer Voice is determined to send positive messages about breast cancer to the community. Later this week they will launch a calendar, `The Australian Face of Breast Cancer Calendar', featuring images of women from different parts of Australia with breast cancer. With the causes of breast cancer still not well understood but the lifetime risk of breast cancer well known, the calendar sends a powerful message about the diversity of women affected by breast cancer. It also sends a positive message about life after diagnosis and treatment.

Last year, the Northern Territory Breast Cancer Voice came up with a novel way of raising awareness of the issue. They put together the first Australian dragon boat racing team, and the team was comprised of breast cancer survivors. For those who do not know, dragon boat racing is an Asian form of rowing. This initiative has been extremely successful, and there are now plans afoot for a national team to compete both nationally and internationally.

It is the advocacy work of Northern Territory Breast Cancer Voice that I want to draw particular attention to this evening. I believe that the capacity for women with a diagnosis of breast cancer to really take control over decision making depends on two things: firstly, women need adequate information about breast cancer and their options for treatment; and, secondly, they need to be able to exercise an authentic choice in relation to these options. There are, however, several issues that limit the capacity of women in the Territory to exercise choice about their treatment for breast cancer.

To address the first issue, access to information, the Northern Territory Breast Cancer Voice is launching a breast cancer book collection this week. These books will be made available to women throughout the Territory through public libraries, and the collection will be updated annually. I applaud the Northern Territory Breast Cancer Voice on this very positive initiative, which will enhance women's access to information about breast cancer.

While information is a vital component of decision making, the capacity to exercise real choice is equally important. But women in the Territory are disadvantaged in several ways when they face a diagnosis of breast cancer. Firstly, there is no specialist breast surgeon or breast cancer oncologist in the Northern Territory. It is true that treating doctors in the Northern Territory have access through telemedicine to specialist advice when considering treatment for their patients. But the breast cancer patient herself is generally not included in these sessions, so she does not have the means to directly ask the specialist the questions that are relevant to her decision about treatment. This is of some consequence, because the issues which affect a woman's decision about breast cancer treatment are highly individual. Unlike her treating doctor, whose main concern is which treatment offers the best chance of a cure, a woman with breast cancer is likely to consider many other issues, and the importance of these issues in a woman's final decision about treatment is not easily understood by others.

There is also the second problem about exercising choice. If a woman with breast cancer is given a choice of a mastectomy and chemotherapy or, alternatively, a lumpectomy and radiotherapy, what does that choice really mean for a woman who lives in the Northern Territory? What are the real implications? The mastectomy option, for some women, means travelling to Darwin or Alice Springs, a situation that has its own problems for women who live in remote parts of the Territoryâfor example, on Croker Island, in Numbulwar or in Tennant Creek. But the other option, the lumpectomy, means the same thing for all women who live in the Northern Territory, that is, travelling interstate for radiotherapy, for a period of six weeks at a time, because the Northern Territory has no radiotherapy facilities. Consider a woman with a partner and children. Does she leave her partner and children for six weeks at a time when they most need each other's support? Can she afford for all of them to travel interstate? Can she afford to spend, herself, six weeks at a time interstate? It is fairly obvious that under these circumstances there is not much of a choice. Generally, she will opt for the mastectomy, for financial and even psychological reasons.

But a further problem besets women in the Northern Territory: there are no specialist breast nurses. The Northern Territory Breast Cancer Voice and other advocacy agencies around the country have been lobbying hard recently for these specialists to be employed, and in this year's federal budget $4.1 million was set aside to provide such professional support for women in rural and remote Australia.

What has happened since the budget? The National Breast Cancer Centre has been given the task of allocating the funds and has called on each state and territory government to provide a representative for a working party. However, both the NBCC and the Territory government have failed to provide an opportunity for consumer input. The Breast Cancer Network of Australia is currently arguing for consumer input on this working party, and from the point of view of women in the Northern Territory this is essential. It is only fair that consumers have a say in the allocation of these funds, understanding as they do the issue of dealing with a diagnosis of breast cancer while living in rural or remote Australia in such conditions as I have outlined tonight.

I understand that all major projects undertaken by the National Breast Cancer Centre are supposed to have consumer input. But this one, with such important implications for women in rural and remote Australia, might have slipped through without consumer input had it not been for the vigilance of the Northern Territory Breast Cancer Voice. I want to pay tribute to and salute the efforts of this organisation for their ongoing demand to be heard by the government. Their commitment to improving the lives of future generations of Australian women, particularly in the Northern Territory and those who have suffered with breast cancer, is inspiring. I sincerely hope that the recent events they have undertaken will not deter them from continuing to speak out in the future.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak briefly tonight on the issue of the direction of Australia's refugee policy, particularly recent statements by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, relating to the people from Kosovo who were admitted to Australia under the safe haven legislation and also proposals he floated last week, supposedly to deal with people smuggling but in effect to further weaken Australia's obligations towards people who apply for protection visas in Australia.

speech.para: The issue of the people from Kosovo who were brought into Australia under the newly created safe haven visas during the recent conflict over there is an issue I particularly want to mention. As the Senate would probably be aware, Australia has recently marked Refugee Week as a way of trying to highlight the importance of recognising and acting upon our obligation towards refugees and to highlight and recognise the extreme suffering that so many people go through and the efforts that Australia can make to try to reduce that suffering.

Yet at the same time as we are supposedly marking Refugee Week, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs announced that he would be proposing to allow people who are applying for refugee status to initially only stay in the country on a temporary basis across the boardâsupposedly due to some link with the increase in people smugglingâand, straight after that, he went down to Tasmania, to the camp where the safe haven visa holders from Kosovo are currently staying, and basically told them to get out by the end of November or they face the risk of being put in detention and forcibly deported. I think that is a disgraceful message to send, particularly in Refugee Week.

The minister followed that up in question time yesterday in response to a dorothy dixer by once again repeating that message. He said that, if the Kosovars who are here were thinking of their own interests, they would take advantage of the allowance that has been offered by Australia of $3,000 per adult and leave here by the end of this monthâ30 October. I think it is a shameful approach from the minister to deign to tell people who have experienced what these people have gone through that he knows what is in their interests, as though he has a full understand ing of what is in their best interests and what they would be facing if they were to return home.

In repeating his threat, he later stated that, if people remain in Australia after their visas expire, there is an obligation on his department to detain them and then remove them from Australia. Whilst he said that he thought nobody would want it to come to that, he said that that was what the outcome would be if you are maintaining a temporary regime. I think the key point to highlight in relation to this issue is the minister's insistence on maintaining a temporary regime. It is a matter of record that the immigration minister did not want to allow any people from Kosovo into Australia at the time the conflict there was at its worst. That was basically overturned in cabinet. The concept of this temporary safe haven visa was born as a political necessity by the cabinet in effect being shamed into responding to the massive wave of concern amongst the Australian public at the time.

We brought these people here to Australia. Often they had little practical choice in the matter, given the situation they were in at the time. When we brought these people into Australia, the government with great fanfare highlighted the compassion that Australia and the Australian government had towards these people. We welcomed them at the airport. There was blanket media coverage about how wonderful it was that Australia was offering a helping hand. Yet just a few months later we are in a situation where, with a few well-placed stories in the media highlighting a couple of safe haven visa holders who had some complaints or concerns about the accommodation, we are trying to turn the whole situation around and basically force them out of the country. It has been said a number of times before that, if it does get to a situation where people are forcibly detained and then removed, it will be interesting to see whether the Prime Minister will be at the airport cheerily waving them goodbye as cheerily as he welcomed them here.

We are basically moving towards a situation where the government will be able to operate this safe haven visa. The concern the Demo crats have is that we will have this form of temporary compassionârefugees with use-by dates that we bring into this country any time there is sufficient public pressure to make the government feel like we need to look compassionate; leave them here until we move on to the next issue and then force them out again. That is what our refugee program is potentially coming to and that is a matter of great concern to the Democrats.

That concern is compounded by some of the proposals the minister put forward last week. It is no secret that the minister has not been keen on the operation of our onshore humanitarian program and people applying for protection visas onshore. He has introduced a number of measures in recent times and continues to try to introduce further measures to make it harder for people to apply for protection visas when they are in Australia. He came forward with a few more proposals last week in a media conference and tried to link those proposed changes to the issue of people smuggling. While this issue is of concern to the Democrats and to most Australians, it is one that is very tenuously linked to people applying for protection visas in Australia.

The government has taken other measures which the Democrats have supported, and we are willing to consider further measures to directly address the problem of people smuggling. I refer here to increasing penalties for people who are involved in organising it, not penalising people who are the victims of it; other legislation that is still before the parliament in relation to border protection measures; other measures that have increased the powers to conduct phone tapping; and measures that go directly to the issue of the organising and implementing of people smuggling.

It seems clear to me that the minister is using that quite legitimate concernâand whipping it up with some well-placed articles in the press to try to generate the community concern that again hordes of people from South-East Asia or further afield are about to descend upon Australiaâas a smokescreen for furthering his own agenda of making it more difficult for people to apply for protection visas in Australia. That is a move that the Democrats have great concerns about. We will examine any proposals in detail when the minister actually puts them forward as legislation or regulations as opposed to press conferences. We have great concerns about the agenda and the aims and the real impact of such moves.

Returning briefly and finally to the issue of Refugee Week, I had the pleasure of attending a media awards night put on by Austcare that highlighted both some of the best efforts of the media around Australia and the issues facing refugees in Australia across a range of categories. I congratulate Austcare for organising those awards. The event sent an important message about the power of the media by highlighting the reality of what refugees face. It is quite easy not to have compassion or concern when reports present the situation as one in which hordes of faceless people are descending here on boats as part of some organised criminal racket, as part of a people smuggling organisation.

But when the media highlights individuals and the personal reality, experiences and suffering that people have to go through, there is quite a different outcome. I would like to congratulate all of those people who were entered for the awards as part of that function. All of those entrants highlighted the reality of the suffering that individual people and families go through. That is what is behind all the public policy debate about refugee issues. We need to remember that it is real people who are being affected by these measures.

I would particularly like to congratulate the winner of the overall award, David Leser. His article `Welcome to Australia', published in the Sydney Morning Herald last year, highlighted in great detail the very real suffering that people were going through because of measures taken which, on the surface, seemed to be reasonable public policy ones. But when one examined the actual impact on individual people, it became clear that immense suffering was happening as a consequence. When the Australian public are made aware of that, their compassion will come to the fore.

talk.start.para: âI recently informed the Senate of the remarkable achievements of the poppy industry in Tasmania. Tonight I have a similar success story: that of the pyrethrum industry in Tasmania. Pyrethrum is a plant which, during December of every year, produces a daisy-like flower with a yellow centre which contains pyrethrins in its seeds. Pyrethrins are six closely related chemicals extracted from the flowers of the pyrethrum plant. They are natural insecticides. The pyrethrum bush grows to a height of 45-75 centimetres, or 18-30 inches, with the flowers growing on long upright stems. It prefers a climate where the temperature is no greater than 30 degrees C and grows best on well-drained soils. Tasmanian senators would be well aware of the soils of the north-west coast of Tasmania. As a perennial plant, pyrethrum grows for many years. In Australia, it can still produce economic yields after seven years but, typically, it is grown from four to five years.

speech.para: In the United States, where the market is huge, pyrethrum has a unique position among pesticides, which has made it is one of the most valuable products in the country. It has the ability to be used at low levels in the control of a broad spectrum of insects, pest resistance is almost non-existent, and it has relatively low toxicity to man and warm blooded animals. One drop of pyrethrum is all that is required in a can of spray. It is often referred to as liquid gold. Pyrethrum has broad use in controlling cockroaches and pests in food handling areas of restaurants. It is widely used as an ingredient in pet shampoos and dips to control fleas and ticks. It is an ingredient in flying-insect killer aerosols for use in homes. Industrial plants use it, and horse stables and dairies use it to control flies and small flying moths. It is even used in ointments and shampoos to control head and body lice on humans.

The Australian pyrethrum industry is the only one of its kind that is fully mechanised from plant seeding right through to harvesting. Kenya is the world's largest producer of pyrethrum, where some 90,000 small-scale farmers hand-harvest the flowers every two to three weeks over a large window of nine to 10 months of the year. Pyrethrum is also grown in Tanzania, Ecuador, Uganda, Rwanda and Papua New Guinea. The Tasmanian crop uses a variety of pyrethrum that has all its flowers blooming at once, unlike the Kenyan product. This ensures maximum efficiency with the harvester fleet. Pyrethrum is harvested in December and January, as my Tasmanian colleagues well know.

The development of the pyrethrum industry in Tasmania started in the 1970s when the University of Tasmania commenced a pyrethrum breeding program with genetic material from India. By 1980, the university had produced several high yielding cultivars which produced one single flush of flowers suitable for mechanical harvesting and it sought commercial partners to finance the development of a pyrethrum industry. CIG Pyrethrum, the Tasmanian government and the University of Tasmania formed a three-part agreement in 1981 to develop a new, fully mechanised world pyrethrum industry. The industry progressed slowly until Ian Folder was appointed manager in 1986. He has achieved enormous gains and taken the venture from humble beginnings to a fully commercialised, sustainable venture.

In 1996, the owner of CIG Pyrethrum, the British Oxygen Company, placed its pyrethrum arm on the market as part of its worldwide rationalisation to concentrate on its core business. A syndicate led by Ian Folder took over the company, which then became Botanical Resources Australia, or BRA, as we know it in Tasmania. The company has five board members, including a former Premier of Tasmania, Mr Robin Gray, as Chairman. One of Botanical Resources' first initiatives as the new owner of the pyrethrum industry was the construction of a state-of-the-art $700,000 prototype carbon dioxide refinery in Ulverstone, on the north-west coast of Tasmania, Senator Denman's home town. Up until this time, the company was only able to undertake primary extraction in Tasmania, sending the oleoresin product to the United States of America for further processing.

An industry strategic plan for all of the local stakeholders identified industry expan sion, research and development and industry diversification as the three key objectives for the future. To ensure it has a technological advantage, the pyrethrum industry has developed innovative research and development programs. Research is funded through a grower contribution of 2.5 per cent of their returns, which is then more than matched by BRA and then again by the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation. Growers, suppliers and BRA staff make up the industry's own Pyrethrum Research and Development Committee, which has the role of determining the priorities for research. The total value of R&D projects for the last three years was in excess of $1.6 million spread across a wide range of projects utilising a large number of highly skilled researchers.

In order to achieve higher yields and high pyrethrins content, a major area of research was the development of a seed based industry to move away from the traditional vegetative propagation method of dividing superior plants into splits. It is well known by all industry participants that cost reductions will come from better weed and disease control and better crop establishment. Yield increases will come from higher crop densities of seeded crops, good seed quality and well-managed crop nutrition.

The first direct drilled seeds were sown in late 1996 and the results since then have been amazing. Direct seeded crops have yielded, on average, a lot higher than transplanted crops and the gross margin to growers has equalled the BRA projections. A new purpose-built laboratory and a new $700,000 crop pelletiser were added to BRA's development site in 1998 in order to handle the extra capacity created by increased plantings and higher yields and to bring all areas together on the one site.

Extensive laboratory procedures test crops before harvest, after harvest and after extraction, and test the refined product. This quickly shows any problem areas where the pyrethrins may be lost during the manufacturing process. Growers are paid on assay results produced by the laboratory. The company has never been a day late in payment and grower trust in this company is absolutely enormous.

During this year, under the direction of BRA's Research and Development Manager, Brian Chung, the company has undertaken an extensive pilot project with the aim of promoting the benefits of electronic commerce within the local farming community and assisting in the administration of pyrethrum issues. A working group consisting of key growers and BRA staff obtained a $108,000 grant from the Tasmanian Electronic Commerce Centre to fund the use of computers for farm management. Systems have been installed on approximately 80 farms, and growers and members of their families are now attending classes to improve their computer and electronic commerce skills. BRA are presently in the process of building a new $1.6 million refinery on their present site and a new storage shed to hold increased harvest tonnage, costing $750,000.

The company now has 20 to 30 per cent of the world pyrethrum market and its share is growing rapidly. This coming season, BRA will have over 200 growers and a planted area of 2,400 hectaresâup significantly from 99 growers and 1,500 hectares of last season. The crop will be harvested by 26 purpose-built harvesters, eight more than last year. The capital being poured into this industry is significant. The company exports 95 per cent of its product and the United States is its largest customer.

BRA are constantly looking for more markets but they have a secure customer base and will not seek additional customers until they can guarantee supply. One customer has contracted forward to the year 2004 and another has recently rolled over their contract to the year 2008âsuch is the confidence in this industry. BRA strives for best practice in pyrethrum oil production and as this company's address is Export Drive, East Ulverstone, one cannot help but think just how appropriate is the situation. With Ian Folder, Brian Chung, their expert staff, extremely dedicated growers and an army of committed consultants and contractors, this innovative Tasmanian industry is in excellent hands.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Livestock Auctions
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1204)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 July 1999:

question.para: (1) Will livestock sold at auction not be defined as food and therefore subject to a goods and services tax (GST).
(2) Will stock sold over the hooks where the point of sale is the point where the carcass is weighed post-slaughter be defined as food and therefore GST free.
(3) Will auctioneers be required to include the GST in the bid price or will they be able to separate out the GST component of each bid to allow buyers to identify the GST component of each purchase.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âThe Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Live animals are specifically excluded from the definition of food. Consequently, livestock sold at auction will be subject to GST where; the seller is registered for GST.
(2) Where stock sold post-slaughter is food for human consumption (is where the animal is of a kind generally used as food for human consumption), the supply will be GST-free.
(3) The treatment of sales of livestock under auction will be consistent with the treatment of other sales which are facilitated by an intermediary.
If the seller is unregistered, no GST will be charged on the sale.
Where a registered business sells livestock at auction, GST will be charged on the sale. The GST will be included in the bid price so that the auctioneer will charge a GST inclusive price.
A registered purchaser will be able to claim an input tax credit equal to 1/11th of the purchase price of the livestock.

subdebateinfo.title: Aviation: High Frequency Radio Distress Calls
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1245)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Re gional Services, upon notice, on 12 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Can any aircraft operating in Australia broadcast a mayday call on high frequency (HF) radio that can be picked up by Air Traffic Services.

(3) In the absence of a domestic HF radio network, will there be locations in Australia where Mayday calls from aircraft will not be received by Air Traffic Services.

Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Airservices Australia has advised that:

(1) Pilots are able to transmit emergency radio calls such as a Mayday on HF radio and, under normal circumstances, these calls will be received by Air Traffic Services. subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Government Levies
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1421)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Is it still the case, as the Senate was advised by Treasury on 1 June 1999, that there is currently no settled policy for deciding which government levies are to be subject to a goods and services tax (GST).

(2) Is it still the case that before a policy on the application of a GST to government levies can be determined, discussion will have to take place with the States to ensure a consistent application of the tax to all similar levies and charges: (a) if so: (i) have discussion on the matter with the States taken place, (ii) how many States have consulted, (iii) when did those consultations take place, (iv) who participated in the consultations, and (v) in each case, what was the outcome of the consultations; and (b) if discussion have not taken place, when are the discussions with each state scheduled to take place.
(3) If the Government has determined a position in relation to the application of the GST to government levies and charges (a) what is that position; and (b) when was it determined.
(4) Will the Treasurer provide: (a) a complete list of government levies and charges that will attract the GST; and (b) a list of levies and charges that will not attract the tax.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âThe Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Intergovernmental Agreement on the Reform of Commonwealth+State Financial Relations was signed by all States and Territories in June 1999. In signing that Agreement, States and Territories agreed that the GST should not apply to some taxes and compulsory charges. The Parties to the Agreement are currently in the process of agreeing on a list of taxes, levies and other charges that should be outside the scope of the GST. The complete list will be promulgated by a determination by the Commonwealth Treasurer as set out in section 81-5 of the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Act 1999 (the GST Act).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 September 1999:

(2) (a) How many such determinations has the Treasurer made; and (b) when was each determination made.

answer.para: A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax Act) 1999 (the GST Act) applies GST to payments of taxes, fees and other charges, except those taxes, fees and other charges that are excluded from the GST by a determination of the Treasurer. talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 20 September 1999:

question.para: With reference to the Minister's decision in August 1999 to lift the 10-year moratorium on food irradiation and to introduce the compulsory labelling of such foods:
(1) (a) What labelling specifications will be required; and (b) what will be the requirements for the label size.
(2) Will labelling be similar to that on cigarette packets clearly stating, `IRRADIATED FOODS'.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Health and Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) and (b) Labelling of irradiated foods will need to comply with current regulations in the Food Standards Code (ie, Standard A1-Labelling and Advertising). This standard describes key criteria that labelling must be in English, distinct, legible, indelible, conspicuously visible and in standard type on the label. There will be no specific requirements for minimum print size for irradiated foods as the labelling of irradiated foods is considered an advisory statement.
(2) The following is an extract from Standard A17 which describes the labelling of irradiated foods:
(a) The label on or attached to a package containing a food that has been processed by ionising radiation must include a statement that the food has been treated with ionising radiation.
Examples:
- `Treated with ionising radiation';
- `Treated with ionising electrons'; and
- `Irradiated (name of food)'.
(b) If a food contains an irradiated food as an ingredient or component, the label on or attached

to a package containing the food must include a statement that the ingredient or component has been treated with ionising radiation, either as part of the declaration of that ingredient or component in an ingredient list or elsewhere on the label.

(c) Where an irradiated food, or a food containing an irradiated food as an ingredient or component, is displayed for retail sale otherwise than in a package, there must be displayed on or in connection with the display of the food a label containing a statement that the food has been treated with ionising radiation, or that it contains an ingredient or component that has been treated with ionising radiation, as the case may be.
(d) Where an irradiated food is sold other than for retail sale, the food must be labelled with:
- a statement that the food has been irradiated;
- the minimum and maximum does of the irradiation;
- the identity of the facility where the food was irradiated; and
- the date or dates of irradiation.
